qas.question: What time period did the Garamantes arrive in?
What did the Garamantes do in order to bring water to   their crops?
How many towns are believed to be found by   Archaeologists?

qas.question: What caused the Roman civilization to collapse?

plausible_answers.text: The ancient Greeks and the Romans

qas.question: What was the name of the people the Garamantes conquered?

plausible_answers.text: by digging tunnels far into the mountains flanking the valley to tap fossil water

qas.question: How did the Greeks get access to water?

context: An urban civilization, the Garamantes, arose around <a0_0><b4_0>500 BCE<b4_0/><a0_0/> in the heart of the Sahara, in a valley that is now called the Wadi al-Ajal in Fezzan, Libya. The Garamantes achieved this development <b8_0>by <a1_0>digging tunnels<a1_0/> far into the mountains flanking the valley to tap fossil water<b8_0/> and bring it to their fields. The Garamantes grew populous and strong, conquering their neighbors and capturing many slaves (which were put to work extending the tunnels). <b7_0>The ancient Greeks and the Romans<b7_0/> knew of the Garamantes and regarded them as uncivilized nomads. However, they traded with the Garamantes, and a Roman bath has been found in the Garamantes capital of Garama. Archaeologists have found <a2_0><b5_0>eight<b5_0/> major towns<a2_0/> and many other important settlements in the Garamantes territory. The Garamantes civilization eventually collapsed after <b6_0>they had <a3_0>depleted available water<a3_0/> in the aquifers<b6_0/> and could no longer sustain the effort to extend the tunnels further into the mountains.
